title: Lessons learned porting 50k loc from Java to Go
Description: Things I've learned porting a 50 thousand lines of code from Java to Go

inline_content.Text: Description: Things I've learned porting a 50 thousand lines of code from Java to Go

title: I was contracted to port a large Java code base to Go.

inline_content.Text: I was contracted to port a large Java code base to Go.

title: The code in question is a Java client for
RavenDB
a
https://ravendb.net/
, a NoSQL JSON document database. Code with tests was around 50 thousand lines.

inline_content.Text: The code in question is a Java client for
RavenDB
, a NoSQL JSON document database. Code with tests was around 50 thousand lines.

title: The result of the port is a
Go client
a
https://github.com/ravendb/ravendb-go-client

inline_content.Text: The result of the port is a
Go client

title: This article describes what I've learn in the process.

inline_content.Text: This article describes what I've learn in the process.
Testing, code coverage

title: Large projects benefit greatly from automated testing and tracking code coverage.

inline_content.Text: Large projects benefit greatly from automated testing and tracking code coverage.

title: I used TravisCI and AppVeyor for testing.
Codecov.io
a
http://codecov.io
for code coverage. There are many other services.

inline_content.Text: I used TravisCI and AppVeyor for testing.
Codecov.io
for code coverage. There are many other services.

title: I used both AppVeyor and TravisCI because a year ago Travis didn't have Windows support and AppVeyor didn't have Linux support.

inline_content.Text: I used both AppVeyor and TravisCI because a year ago Travis didn't have Windows support and AppVeyor didn't have Linux support.

title: Today if I was settings this up from scratch, I would stick with just AppVeyor, as it can now do both Linux and Windows testing and the future of TravisCI is murky, after it was acquired by private equity firm and reportedly fired the original dev team.

inline_content.Text: Today if I was settings this up from scratch, I would stick with just AppVeyor, as it can now do both Linux and Windows testing and the future of TravisCI is murky, after it was acquired by private equity firm and reportedly fired the original dev team.

title: Codecov is barely adequate. For Go, they count non-code lines (comments etc.) as not executed. It's impossible to get 100% code coverage as reported by the tool. Coveralls seems to have the same problem.

inline_content.Text: Codecov is barely adequate. For Go, they count non-code lines (comments etc.) as not executed. It's impossible to get 100% code coverage as reported by the tool. Coveralls seems to have the same problem.

title: It's better than nothing but there's an opportunity to do things better, especially for Go programs.

inline_content.Text: It's better than nothing but there's an opportunity to do things better, especially for Go programs.
Go's race detector is great

title: Parts of the code use concurrency and it's really easy to get concurrency wrong.

inline_content.Text: Parts of the code use concurrency and it's really easy to get concurrency wrong.

title: Go provides race detector that can be enabled with
-race
c
flag during compilation.

inline_content.Text: Go provides race detector that can be enabled with
-race
flag during compilation.

title: It slows down the program but additional checks can detect if you're concurrently modifying the same memory location.

inline_content.Text: It slows down the program but additional checks can detect if you're concurrently modifying the same memory location.

title: I always run tests with
-race
c
enabled and it alerted me to numerous races, which allowed me to fix them promptly.

inline_content.Text: I always run tests with
-race
enabled and it alerted me to numerous races, which allowed me to fix them promptly.
Building custom tools for testing

title: In a project that big it's impossible to verify correctness by inspection. Too much code to hold in your head at once.

inline_content.Text: In a project that big it's impossible to verify correctness by inspection. Too much code to hold in your head at once.

title: When a test fails, it can be a challenge to figure out why just from the information in the test failure.

inline_content.Text: When a test fails, it can be a challenge to figure out why just from the information in the test failure.

title: Database client driver talks to RavenDB database server over HTTP using JSON to encode commands and results.

inline_content.Text: Database client driver talks to RavenDB database server over HTTP using JSON to encode commands and results.

title: When porting Java tests to Go, it was very useful to be able to capture the HTTP traffic between Java client and server and compare it with HTTP traffic generated by  Go port.

inline_content.Text: When porting Java tests to Go, it was very useful to be able to capture the HTTP traffic between Java client and server and compare it with HTTP traffic generated by  Go port.

title: I built custom tools to help me do that.

inline_content.Text: I built custom tools to help me do that.

title: For capturing HTTP traffic in Java client, I built a
logging HTTP proxy
a
https://github.com/kjk/httplogproxy
in Go and directed Java client to use that HTTP proxy.

inline_content.Text: For capturing HTTP traffic in Java client, I built a
logging HTTP proxy
in Go and directed Java client to use that HTTP proxy.

title: For Go client, I built
a hook in the library
a
https://github.com/ravendb/ravendb-go-client/blob/20fade9ee6d22d60c7babf4a155c4de5bf4cfd3b/request_executor.go#L23
that allows to intercept HTTP requests. I used it to log the traffic to a file.

inline_content.Text: For Go client, I built
a hook in the library
that allows to intercept HTTP requests. I used it to log the traffic to a file.

title: I was then able to compare HTTP traffic generated by Java client to traffic generated by my Go port and spot the differences.

inline_content.Text: I was then able to compare HTTP traffic generated by Java client to traffic generated by my Go port and spot the differences.
Porting process

title: You can't just start porting 50 thousand lines of code in random order. Without testing and validating after every little step I'm sure I would be defeated by complexity.

inline_content.Text: You can't just start porting 50 thousand lines of code in random order. Without testing and validating after every little step I'm sure I would be defeated by complexity.

title: I was new to RavenDB and Java code base. My first step was to get a high-level understanding how Java code works.

inline_content.Text: I was new to RavenDB and Java code base. My first step was to get a high-level understanding how Java code works.

title: At the core the client talks to the server via HTTP protocol. I captured the traffic, looked at it and wrote the simplest Go code to talk the server.

inline_content.Text: At the core the client talks to the server via HTTP protocol. I captured the traffic, looked at it and wrote the simplest Go code to talk the server.

title: When that was working it gave me confidence I'll be able to replicate the functionality.

inline_content.Text: When that was working it gave me confidence I'll be able to replicate the functionality.

title: My first milestone was to port enough code to be able to port the simplest Java test.

inline_content.Text: My first milestone was to port enough code to be able to port the simplest Java test.

title: I used a combination of bottom-up and top-down approach.

inline_content.Text: I used a combination of bottom-up and top-down approach.

title: Bottom-up part is where I identified the code at the bottom of call chain responsible for sending commands to the server and parsing responses and ported those.

inline_content.Text: Bottom-up part is where I identified the code at the bottom of call chain responsible for sending commands to the server and parsing responses and ported those.

title: The top-down part is where I stepped through the test I was porting to identify which parts of the code need to be ported to implement that part.

inline_content.Text: The top-down part is where I stepped through the test I was porting to identify which parts of the code need to be ported to implement that part.

title: After successfully porting the first step, the rest of the work was porting one test at a time, also porting all the necessary code needed to make the test work.

inline_content.Text: After successfully porting the first step, the rest of the work was porting one test at a time, also porting all the necessary code needed to make the test work.

title: After the tests were ported and passing, I did improvements to make the code more Go-ish.

inline_content.Text: After the tests were ported and passing, I did improvements to make the code more Go-ish.

title: I believe that this step-by-step approach was crucial to completing the work.

inline_content.Text: I believe that this step-by-step approach was crucial to completing the work.

title: Psychologically, when faced with a year-long project, it's important to have smaller, intermediate milestones. Hitting those kept me motivated.

inline_content.Text: Psychologically, when faced with a year-long project, it's important to have smaller, intermediate milestones. Hitting those kept me motivated.

title: Keeping the code compiling, running and passing tests at all times is also good. Allowing bugs to accumulate can make it very hard to fix them when you finally get to it.

inline_content.Text: Keeping the code compiling, running and passing tests at all times is also good. Allowing bugs to accumulate can make it very hard to fix them when you finally get to it.

title: Challenges of porting Java to Go

inline_content.Text: Challenges of porting Java to Go

title: The objective of the port was to keep it as close as possible to Java code base, as it needs to be kept in sync in the future with Java changes.

inline_content.Text: The objective of the port was to keep it as close as possible to Java code base, as it needs to be kept in sync in the future with Java changes.

title: I'm somewhat surprised how much code I ported in a line-by-line fashion. The most time consuming part of the port was reversing the order of variable declaration, from Java's
type name
c
to Go's
name type
c
. I wish there was a tool that would do that part for me.

inline_content.Text: I'm somewhat surprised how much code I ported in a line-by-line fashion. The most time consuming part of the port was reversing the order of variable declaration, from Java's
type name
to Go's
name type
. I wish there was a tool that would do that part for me.
String vs. string

title: In Java,
String
c
is an object that really is an reference (a pointer). As a result, a string can be
null
c

inline_content.Text: In Java,
String
is an object that really is an reference (a pointer). As a result, a string can be
null

title: In Go
string
c
is a value type. It can't be
null
c
, only empty.

inline_content.Text: In Go
string
is a value type. It can't be
null
, only empty.

title: It wasn't a big deal and most of the time I could mechanically replace
null
c
with
c

inline_content.Text: It wasn't a big deal and most of the time I could mechanically replace
null
with
Errors vs. exceptions

title: Java uses exceptions to communicate errors.

inline_content.Text: Java uses exceptions to communicate errors.
Go returns values of
error
interface.

title: Porting wasn't difficult but it did require changing lots of function signatures to return error values and propagate them along the call chain.

inline_content.Text: Porting wasn't difficult but it did require changing lots of function signatures to return error values and propagate them along the call chain.
Generics
Go doesn't have them (yet).

title: Porting generic APIs was the biggest challenge.

inline_content.Text: Porting generic APIs was the biggest challenge.

title: Here's an example of a generic method in Java:

inline_content.Text: Here's an example of a generic method in Java:

title: public <T> T load(Class<T> clazz, String id) {

content_resolved.code: public <T> T load(Class<T> clazz, String id) {

inline_content.Text: And the caller:

title: In Go, I used two strategies.

inline_content.Text: In Go, I used two strategies.

title: One is to use
interface{}
c
, which combines value and its type, similar to
object
c
in Java. This is not preferred approach. While it works, operating on
interface{}
c
is clumsy for the user of the library.

inline_content.Text: One is to use
interface{}
, which combines value and its type, similar to
object
in Java. This is not preferred approach. While it works, operating on
interface{}
is clumsy for the user of the library.

title: In some cases I was able to use reflection and the above code was ported as:

inline_content.Text: In some cases I was able to use reflection and the above code was ported as:

title: func Load(result interface{}, id string) error

content_resolved.code: func Load(result interface{}, id string) error

title: I could use reflection to query type of
result
c
and create values of that type from JSON document.

inline_content.Text: I could use reflection to query type of
result
and create values of that type from JSON document.
And the caller side:
Function overloading

title: Go doesn't have it (and most likely will never have it).

inline_content.Text: Go doesn't have it (and most likely will never have it).

title: I can't say I found a good solution to port those.

inline_content.Text: I can't say I found a good solution to port those.

title: In some cases overloading was used to create shorter helpers:

inline_content.Text: In some cases overloading was used to create shorter helpers:

title:
void foo(int a, String b) {}
void foo(int a) { foo(a, null); }

content_resolved.code:
void foo(int a, String b) {}
void foo(int a) { foo(a, null); }

title: Sometimes I would just drop the shorter helper.

inline_content.Text: Sometimes I would just drop the shorter helper.
Sometimes I would write 2 functions:

title:
func foo(a int) {}
func fooWithB(a int, b string) {}

content_resolved.code:
func foo(a int) {}
func fooWithB(a int, b string) {}

title: When number of potential arguments was large I would sometimes do:

inline_content.Text: When number of potential arguments was large I would sometimes do:
Inheritance

title: Go is not especially object-oriented and doesn't have inheritance.

inline_content.Text: Go is not especially object-oriented and doesn't have inheritance.

title: Simple cases of inheritance can be ported with embedding.

inline_content.Text: Simple cases of inheritance can be ported with embedding.
Can sometimes be ported as:

title: We've embedded
A
c
inside
B
c
, so it'll inherit all the methods.

inline_content.Text: We've embedded
A
inside
B
, so it'll inherit all the methods.

title: It doesn't work for virtual functions.

inline_content.Text: It doesn't work for virtual functions.

title: There is no good way to directly port code that uses virtual functions.

inline_content.Text: There is no good way to directly port code that uses virtual functions.

title: One option to emulate it is to use embedding and structs with function pointers. This essentially re-implements virtual table that Java gives you for free as part of
object
c
implementation.

inline_content.Text: One option to emulate it is to use embedding and structs with function pointers. This essentially re-implements virtual table that Java gives you for free as part of
object
implementation.

title: Another option is to write a stand-alone function that dispatches the right function for a given type based on the type.

inline_content.Text: Another option is to write a stand-alone function that dispatches the right function for a given type based on the type.
Interfaces

title: Both Java and Go have interfaces but they are different things, like apples and salami.

inline_content.Text: Both Java and Go have interfaces but they are different things, like apples and salami.

title: A few times I did create a Go interface type that replicated Java interface.

inline_content.Text: A few times I did create a Go interface type that replicated Java interface.

title: In more cases I dropped interfaces and instead exposed concrete structs in the API.

inline_content.Text: In more cases I dropped interfaces and instead exposed concrete structs in the API.
Circular imports between packages

title: Java allows circular imports between packages.

inline_content.Text: Java allows circular imports between packages.
Go does not.

title: As a result I was not able to replicate the package structure of Java code in my port.

inline_content.Text: As a result I was not able to replicate the package structure of Java code in my port.

title: For simplicity I went with a single package. Not ideal, because it ended up being very large package. So large, in fact, that Go 1.10 couldn't handle so many source files in a single package on Windows. Luckily it was fixed in Go 1.11.

inline_content.Text: For simplicity I went with a single package. Not ideal, because it ended up being very large package. So large, in fact, that Go 1.10 couldn't handle so many source files in a single package on Windows. Luckily it was fixed in Go 1.11.
Private, public, protected

title: Go's designers are under-appreciated. Their ability to simplify concepts is unmatched and access control is one example of that.

inline_content.Text: Go's designers are under-appreciated. Their ability to simplify concepts is unmatched and access control is one example of that.

title: Other languages gravitate to fine-grained access control: public, private, protected specified with the smallest possible granularity (per class field and method).

inline_content.Text: Other languages gravitate to fine-grained access control: public, private, protected specified with the smallest possible granularity (per class field and method).

title: As a result a library implementing some functionality has the same access to other classes in the same library as external code using that library.

inline_content.Text: As a result a library implementing some functionality has the same access to other classes in the same library as external code using that library.

title: Go simplified that by only having public vs. private and scoping access to package level.

inline_content.Text: Go simplified that by only having public vs. private and scoping access to package level.

title: That makes more sense. When I write a library to, say, parse markdown, I don't want expose internals of the implementation to users of the library. But hiding those internals from myself is counter-productive.

inline_content.Text: That makes more sense. When I write a library to, say, parse markdown, I don't want expose internals of the implementation to users of the library. But hiding those internals from myself is counter-productive.

title: Java programmers noticed that issue and sometimes they use an interface as a hack to fix over-exposed classes. By returning an interface instead of a a concrete class, they hide some of the public APIs available to direct users of the class behind an interface.

inline_content.Text: Java programmers noticed that issue and sometimes they use an interface as a hack to fix over-exposed classes. By returning an interface instead of a a concrete class, they hide some of the public APIs available to direct users of the class behind an interface.
Concurrency

title: Go's concurrency is simply the best and a built-in race detector is of great help in repelling concurrency bugs.

inline_content.Text: Go's concurrency is simply the best and a built-in race detector is of great help in repelling concurrency bugs.

title: That being said, in my first porting pass I went with emulating Java APIs. For example, I implemented a facsimile of Java's
CompletableFuture
c
class.

inline_content.Text: That being said, in my first porting pass I went with emulating Java APIs. For example, I implemented a facsimile of Java's
CompletableFuture
class.

title: Only after the code was working I would re-structure it to be more idiomatic Go.

inline_content.Text: Only after the code was working I would re-structure it to be more idiomatic Go.
Fluent function chaining

title: RavenDB has very sophisticated querying capabilities. Java client uses method chaining for building queries:

inline_content.Text: RavenDB has very sophisticated querying capabilities. Java client uses method chaining for building queries:

title: This only works in languages that communicate errors via exceptions. When a function additionally returns an error, it's no longer possible to chain it like that.

inline_content.Text: This only works in languages that communicate errors via exceptions. When a function additionally returns an error, it's no longer possible to chain it like that.

title: To replicate chaining in Go I used an "stateful error" approach:

inline_content.Text: To replicate chaining in Go I used an "stateful error" approach:
This can be chained:
JSON marshaling

title: Java doesn't have a built-in marshaling and the client uses Jackson JSON library.

inline_content.Text: Java doesn't have a built-in marshaling and the client uses Jackson JSON library.

title: Go has JSON support in standard library but it doesn't provide as many hooks for tweaking marshaling process.

inline_content.Text: Go has JSON support in standard library but it doesn't provide as many hooks for tweaking marshaling process.

title: That being said I didn't try to match all of Java's functionality as what is provided by Go's built-in JSON support seems to be flexible enough.

inline_content.Text: That being said I didn't try to match all of Java's functionality as what is provided by Go's built-in JSON support seems to be flexible enough.
Go code is shorter

title: This is not so much a property of Java but the culture which dictates what is considered an idiomatic code.

inline_content.Text: This is not so much a property of Java but the culture which dictates what is considered an idiomatic code.

title: In Java setter and getter methods are common. As a result, Java code:

inline_content.Text: In Java setter and getter methods are common. As a result, Java code:
ends up in Go as:

title: 3 lines vs. 11 lines. It does add up when you have a lot of classes with lots of members.

inline_content.Text: 3 lines vs. 11 lines. It does add up when you have a lot of classes with lots of members.

title: Most other code ends up being of equivalent length.

inline_content.Text: Most other code ends up being of equivalent length.
Notion for organizing the work

title: I'm a heavy user of
Notion.so
a
https://www.notion.so
. Simplifying a lot, Notion is a hierarchical note taking application. Think a cross of Evernote and a wiki, exquisitely designed and implemented by top notch software designers.

inline_content.Text: I'm a heavy user of
Notion.so
